title: Corrections & Amplifications
text:
Bill Gates's Cascade Investment LLC agreed to pay $2.21 billion for a 23.75% stake in Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts held by Prince al-Waleed bin Talal's Kingdom Holding Co., in a deal that values the hotel operator at $10 billion. In some editions Thursday, a Page One What's News summary incorrectly said the deal was valued at $10 billion.

---

The District of Columbia was incorrectly labeled as a state in a graphic with an Aug. 31 U.S. News article about Covid-19 hospitalizations. The same error appeared in an Aug. 26 graphic with a U.S. News article about congressionally appropriated funds for rental assistance.

(See: "U.S. News: Covid-19 Hospitalizations Approach a Peak" -- WSJ Aug. 31, 2021 and "U.S. News: U.S. Struggles to Deliver Aid to Renters --- Just a fraction of promised assistance reached tenants and landlords through July" -- WSJ Aug. 26, 2021)

---

The surname of Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani, a former executive at Theranos Inc., was misspelled in one instance as Bawlani in some editions Thursday in a Business & Finance article about the criminal trial of company founder Elizabeth Holmes.

---

The European Union will require new legal guarantees about data privacy on existing business contracts that involve international data transfers starting Dec. 27, 2022. A Technology article on Tuesday about the EU rules incorrectly said December without specifying the year.

(See: "Technology: EU Curbs U.S. Data Transfers Amid Concerns Over Privacy" -- WSJ Sept. 7, 2021)

---

Revisions made to a graphic that appeared with a Sports article on Saturday depicting The Wall Street Journal's college football "2021 Grid of Shame" made references to the team rankings incorrect in the accompanying article. The article was written for a grid with a horizontal axis showing team performance ranging from weakling to powerhouse, and a vertical axis showing team behavior ranging from embarrassing to admirable. When the axes were reversed, descriptions of which quadrant a team resides in became incorrect. A link to the article and grid the way they were intended to appear can be found at WSJ.com/Corrections.

---

Notice to readers

Wall Street Journal staff members are working remotely during the pandemic. For the foreseeable future, please send reader comments only by email or phone, using the contacts below, not via U.S. Mail.

---

Readers can alert The Wall Street Journal to any errors in news articles by e-mailing wsjcontact@wsj.com or by calling 888-410-2667.
